Situation1: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle ready, eyes scanning the water. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce every safety rule, no exceptions. Today, a few swimmers kept slipping into the shallow area without supervision, and I felt the weight of responsibility pressing on me. But my shift was ending, and I needed to get to the polling station before it closed. When I arrived, the line was long, but I was relieved to see it moving quickly. Suddenly, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name fit, but the new line was barely moving. The official’s instructions were clear, and as a voter, I was supposed to follow them. But as a lifeguard, I was trained to assess situations and act for safety and efficiency, not just follow orders blindly. I felt torn—should I obey the official, or stay in the faster line to make sure I could vote before my break ended? The expectations of both roles clashed inside me, and I stood frozen, heart pounding, caught between duty and obedience.
